swift/cli/relinker.py.message: is there any ‘etc’? I wonder if it might be better to stick with the list of known lock files?

I don't think so, but at the same time, the listdir is unavoidable, since you can have N replication locks.

Originally, I was planning on unlinking every non-directory but then I got skittish when it caused test_cleanup_old_part_careful to fail. I figured "all locks" should be a decent middle-ground; they are inherently transient things, and if there isn't anything else in the partition, there's no reason to keep it around.

😮 I need to check my assumptions more often. Yup, it's just the one replication lock! And looking into the history a bit, there's only ever been the one replication lock. I definitely *was* thinking about the device-level locks.

If we're going to take the replication lock here, we've gotta think through the order in which should they be taken. Looks like ssync_receiver is the only thing that takes the replication lock; that's fairly high-level, then it goes down and opens up diskfiles. Since those could need to be quarantined, it may need to take the partition lock, too -- so I guess I should match that order, to avoid deadlocks?

There's only one .lock-replication file in a partition dir though - the multiple concurrency locks are at the device level:

  ├── node3
│   ├── sdb3
│   │   └── objects-1
│   │       └── 396
│   │           ├── .lock
│   │           └── 784
│   │               └── 633ab34b43784a4a069092fe954ee784
│   └── sdb7
│       ├── .lock
│       ├── .lock-1
│       └── objects-1
│           └── 396
│               ├── .lock
│               ├── .lock-replication
│               └── 784
│                   └── 633ab34b43784a4a069092fe954ee784
└── node4

ok, so we lock_path to delete the files, it itself will places a lock file file which we then delete. In essence unlocking it, so something else could come in a lock it in the meantime.. but I guess if that's the case then we probably don't want to delete the directory.

But if there are some other lock in there how do we know it's not currently being used? Should we attempt a write lock and if so, delete it then? But that would mean we'd need to know what our own lock_path lock is.. though it should just be the .lock.

From a quick look at the code it's mostly the relinker and the rehashing that locks the partition dir. And we did confirm there was no hashes.. so unless something is actaully causing a rehash it should be safe.

Agree, we should probably take each lock before deleting it. That way we know we're not deleting some other process's lock.

I think it is ok to delete the lock we've taken if we're careful what else we do inside the context manager (could be worth a comment to remind us): another process can then immediately take the lock while we're still in the lock_path context manager, but then os.rmdir will fail.

I'm a little worried about B and C writing concurrently after

* A takes the lock
* B tries to take the lock and blocks
* A deletes the lock file
* C takes the (new) lock
* A releases the (old) lock

Looks like B acquires the *old* lock:

 vagrant@saio:~/swift$ lsof -p 464829 | grep /tmp
 python  464829 vagrant    3wW     REG    8,1        0   3763 /tmp/.lock (deleted)
 vagrant@saio:~/swift$ lsof -p 464840 | grep /tmp
 python  464840 vagrant    3wW     REG    8,1        0   7927 /tmp/.lock

I almost want to take the old lock, delete the lock file, then *never release it* to ensure that any blocked processes timeout -- but then I'd worry about the file descriptor leak. I guess the next best thing would be to stat the lock file after acquiring it, compare inodes against an fstat of the open fd, and raise a "Timeout" if they differ.

OK so the idea here, just to make sure I'm on the same page, is to take a replication lock in essence so we know there is no other replication happening, because if somehow there was on the partition then we'd be waiting for the lock. And a .lock that we normally use, this should block the hashes at the same time.

Then we can clean up hashes.pkl, hashes.invalid, then finally clear the hashes .lock and the finally clear the replication lock we have held?

The lock_path function takes a limit, where you can control how many locks there should be to a particular location.. which is interesting, but I can't see anywhere we use it. So just taking the single .lock and .lock-replication should be ok. But it's an interesting feature to remember if we ever want to limit access to places for whatever reason.

limit is used in replication_lock for the device level locks, to allow concurrency, but not at partition level:

https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/7087fb0d7ed6e36cc2d120eb6d8125257c8c7089/swift/obj/diskfile.py#L1361-L1382

there doesn't seem to be any test coverage for the locks being taken - I hacked something together in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/792369 to cover .lock-replication but found it harder to target the plain .lock
right, let's not unlink hashes.* if get_hashes failed to run
ok. this is going to lock the whole device, but only while a partition is rm'd, and the only other process to compete for that lock is ssync which should be inactive during part power increase.

I still don't get a test failure if this regresses e.g.

  hashes = None

swift/common/utils.py.message: I'm curious that you haven't used DEFAULT_LOCK_TIMEOUT as the kwarg default...but wondering if that has to do with when the kwarg default is initialised w.r.t. monkey patching in the tests? Yeah, it's for the sake of monkey-patching. The default args get evaluated when lock_path gets defined. *Maybe* we could do something clever with ctypes or something so we've got a pointer to a double that we could manipulate, but that seems not worth the effort.

test/unit/cli/test_relinker.py.message: with the current change, we should check some other .lock_blah file also gets removed
would be good to have a test that covers a dir preventing the partition removal
Reading the diskfile replication_lock code I only see one .lock-replication file getting created, but at the device level there could be .lock, .lock-1, .lock-2 etc

this does not fail when I revert the relinker taking the partition lock, because the preceding get_hashes raises LockTimeout so that the relinker does not even attempt to remove the partition dir.

So, the test *is* verifying the try/except around get_hashes, but not what the test purports to verify.

Even if get_hashes had run, invalidate_hash has also failed due to the lock being held! This is the kind of tangle I ran into trying to construct this test. It probably needs the lock to be taken more surgically than 'for the whole relinker cycle'.
Good point; I'll see what I can do about making this test more targeted. Still, I'm glad I did it this way as a first pass so I found all the other bits that needed to catch LockTimeouts ;-)

the relinker is unable to rehash, but also unable to take the lock to rm, so this doesn't verify that the rehash LockTimeout sets hashes to a truthy value - which is why I had to mock get_hashes in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/792556/1/test/unit/cli/test_relinker.py

kubernetes/k8s-pod-recovery/centos/files.message: I think the time to bring up the sriovdp pod may depend on the number of other pods that are initializing in the system.  I think we had to change the timeout previously in a similar case from 60s -> 360s when there were hundreds of user pods being initialized on startup.

Good advice, thanks. Given that the wait command exits as soon as the daemonset is ready, extending it here makes sense.

Done.

I would recommend indicating in the log entry that a timeout happened.  Give the end user as much useful info as to what happened as you can, without turning it into a novel.  eg.

ERROR "SRIOV device plugin timed out on ready wait.  Continuing anyway.  SRIOV pods may not recover."

Thanks, that's much clearer. 

Done

What happens if on reboot, that one of the SRIOV pods is stuck in a Unknown state? Will this wait 6 minutes before timing out? And in this case will the restart-on-reboot pods be not have the correct information?

I'm thinking that we need to take a more deterministic action here, should we just check/delete the sriov pod first so it clears any bad state, wait for the rollout status, then handle the restart-on-reboot pods? If we do this can the timeout be smaller that 360s?

That's a good point. I can try it with 
kubectl rollout restart daemonset -n kube-system kube-sriov-device-plugin-amd64
and then watch the status.

Will the rollout restart, restart the pods on every node? Can you target to just the node that is rebooting (i.e --field-selector=spec.nodeName=${HOST})? I'm thinking of a 2+N environment with SRIOV pods running on worker nodes that have not rebooted. We would want to leave those pods unaffected.

I think we can use the rollout restart first to reset the device plugin pods, but I don't believe that will allow us to lower the timeout, because it does not negate the scenario Steve mentioned where there are a large amount of user pods and the system takes a long time to bring everything up.

Adding the restart will ensure we aren't falsely waiting for the daemonset when the pods are stuck in an unknown state though, which is good.

Does that seem like an acceptable approach? I'm running a test with that configuration now.

Thanks for the feedback, I've implemented that approach. I'm now deleting the local device-plugin pod only and then watching for the daemonset to be available.

I have also added logic to only restart the device-plugin if there are labeled pods present that would be using it. That way we skip this step if we are on a system with no SRIOV pods.

I hope this addresses all of your points.
Does SRIOVDP get used later on?  If not, why not just ditch it and test $? directly?
Done
I meant test $? directly instead of storing it in an intermediate variable.  Not subshell the whole kubectl command.
Oops my apologies... trying to go too quick.
Let's say there's an SR-IOV device plugin pod that is _not_ on this host that is not 'ready' for whatever reason.  Will this then delay the full 360s?
Implemented your suggestion and limited the wait to only consider the local node. Now k8s-pod-recovery only cares about device-plugin pods running locally.

Just wondering if it is worth looking at the return code of the above command and reporting if the delete fails?  I don't understand enough of what is going on here to know.  I'm just looking at the structure of the code.  Personally I think that return codes should always be checked unless it truly doesn't matter if it failed or not, and in that case, it should probably have a comment saying so.  But this isn't the only call to kubectl in this script that doesn't have its return checked.  This whole script just looks like it was hastily coded for success path and not for debugging when things go wrong.
Done

Add the --wait=false option to the 'kubectl delete pods' otherwise the delete may hang indefinitely if something is really wrong. We'll leverage the 360s timeout for the Ready condition below. We do this for all the other 'kubectl delete pods' in this script for this reason.

I guess what I'm trying to say here is that I wouldn't necessarily block this code from going in, but would feel better if there is a story captured somewhere to improve the error paths in this script.
I opened https://bugs.launchpad.net/starlingx/+bug/1930606 to investigate code cleanup of this script at some point in the future

openstackclient/compute/v2/server.py.message:
Is this command not present in 16.2?  Checking osc I see the following:
(overcloud) [stack@undercloud-0 ~]$ openstack server migration --help
Command "server" matches:
  server add fixed ip
  server add floating ip
  server add network
...

I do see 'server migrate' but it currently does not list any confirm flag:
(overcloud) [stack@undercloud-0 ~]$ openstack server migrate --help | grep -i confirm
(overcloud) [stack@undercloud-0 ~]$

It's not present in Train, no. 'server migration confirm' was only added in Wallaby and it replaced the otherwise identical 'server migrate confirm' command which was added in Ussuri. Both are equivalent to 'server resize confirm' since a resize and a cold migration are effectively the same thing under the hood, with the only difference being the flavour doesn't change in a cold migration.

Yes please. I think this is the prudent thing to do.

> One concern is that the new parameter can create another bug where we can reparent an RP from None to one and combine two RP trees into one tree even when we set "allow_reparenting=False". 

I'm not sure it is a bug. Today we already allow changing the parent from None to a valid RP UUID. If that was not considered dangerous in the past I don't see why it would be moved under the protection of new "allow_reparenting=True" query parameter. Moreover it would be a strange user experience to disallow something in a new microversion by default that was accepted in an older one.

> If the new query parameter is needed only because we haven't supported it so far, isn't that what microversion is for?

The argument was on the PTG that simply using the microversion to prevent unintentional re-parenting is not enough as later when newer microversions are added to the PUT /resource_providers API then the user might want to use the new feature but still want to avoid unintentional re-parenting. As microversioning uses an increasing integer value, we cannot selectively disable re-parenting and enable the newer features on the same API resource.

Well, either way is okay. One concern is that the new parameter can create another bug where we can reparent an RP from None to one and combine two RP trees into one tree even when we set "allow_reparenting=False". If the new query parameter is needed only because we haven't supported it so far, isn't that what microversion is for?
None?
Done
either way, I'm all up about saying that if you call this new API method, you know what you do so it's a caller issue.
That is an alternative yes. But on the PTG it was raised that we need an extra safety check.
this is surely the responsibility of the caller, as I said above. That being said, I wonder whether we should tho verify that there are no allocations and asking the caller to force this if so ?
Technically we can do it but I don't want to overcomplicate the behavior.
yep
Ack

when we discussed this at the PTG, I told about PATCH for saying "yeah, as a client, I know I'll force". I wasn't really opiniated about PATCH so I understand your point.

That being said, there is one other alternative that you haven't mentioned, which is by using HTTP header like 'Force'. Thoughts on it instead of this very specific and hacky query param ?
True I can add that as an alternative. I think the header is a lot less tight to a certain API than the query parameter hence it feels a bit less clean that the query parameter.
I'm eventually OK with this.
Is this mention of "new placement API microversion" talking about the proposal in this spec or a future proposal? I was thinking it's talking about this spec proposal.

i prefer this over force but as i not below 

PUT /resource-providers/{uuid}/parent_uuid/{parent} with an empty body

im not -1 on this proposal however.

if other wanted a shorter QA name you could have just

reparent=True

as long as we dont use force=true i think im ok with most name for the arg however.

I think I prefer this over "force" too but I'm realizing this terminology doesn't cover the un-parenting case, right? That is, when we say "allow_reparenting=True" we are indicating that the API should go ahead and re-parent or un-parent if that's what's being requested, but the word is only saying "reparenting". I guess you would say you can re-parent to None so it's still re-parenting.

Admittedly I'm now starting to wonder whether the query parameter addition is helpful or if it could be cumbersome. For the latter I wonder would it result in API callers simply adding "allow_reparenting=True" all the time, making it meaningless. Or if callers could be rejected when they change parent_uuid and then the caller just calls again with allow_reparenting=True.

I'm starting to think that maybe the combination of (1) new microversion and (2) the code comment that documented the reasoning behind rejecting re-parenting and un-parenting requests might be indicating that a "allow" or "force" keyword isn't really needed. The new microversion (1) signals the change/addition of behavior to the API. And it's possible that if the issues in (2) had not been present (loops and orphans), then the PUT API would have allowed re-parenting and un-parenting by default, back when it was first implemented.

I keep thinking that the query param seems kind of redundant when changing the parent_uuid inherently means "re-parent/un-parent". If you're even changing it, you know you're re-parenting, so if you also have to also pass a query param, it would be like saying, "I want to re-parent this RP" twice.

Based on this, I think I have a slight preference for "do nothing" now.
this is still my preference for what its worth but its not a stong preference.
nit: parameter

ya the header woudl be annoyign to type and im not sure it will be captured in loging as well as some other approaches. its also not a common paridime for this type of api.
we use this patern for thing like keystone auth that is transfromed by midelware but i dont think we normally use headers in project apis so -1 to using a header.

Honestly, I tried a lot to think about this spec by looking at some kind of RESTful question.

That said, the current API endpoint is not RESTful : you can PUT a resource with some parameters with all the resource parameters but what you'll get will depend on whether the current resource parameter is None or other.

In a RESTful API, we could accept PUT to modify all the resource parameters and we would use PATCH for only updating the ones we'd like to modify :
https://restful-api-design.readthedocs.io/en/latest/methods.html

That being said, this would mean changing all the existing PUT calls depending on the new microversion, and just for the sake of being RESTful... 

So, honestly, I'm done with this and I wonder whether we should do like Nova : use some sub-resource for PUT :

 PUT /resource-providers/{uuid}/force

This isn't great but this would explicitely mean this subresource would accept to change *every* single Resource Provider parameter.

Thoughts ?

as mentioned on IRC i think i would prefer

PUT /resource-providers/{uuid}/parent_uuid/{parent} with an empty body

if we were to use a sub resouces not  PUT /resource-providers/{uuid}/force


PUT /resource-providers/{uuid}/parent_uuid/{parent} woudl patch 
/resource-providers/{uuid} with the new parent uuid.

the limitation to taking this approch woudl be that we can only update one filed the parent_uuid in this api call.

i do not think we intend to update the parent and the name or uuid concurently for any of the usecase we currently have so this restriction might be fine.

manifests/haproxy.pp.message:
Why are we using keepalive probes for heat only? Have we considered the overhead wrt additional network packets?

I would probably like to see if this resolves any of the current problems.

@Rabi, I provided an explanation in the commit message, and in the targeted bug 1882927 there is a link to bz 1844357 that expains the case in details. Missing hearbeats as the root cause that is my assumption. If you think this patch has to be blocked until additional testing results provided, cuold you please go for it and reproduce the situation similar to the linked bz 1844357 and see if tcpka added resolves the issue? I'd gladly assist on the testing and reproducing. Let me know.

tl;dr of that bz - the problem this solves (for Heat use cases in NFV in the first place) is cascading failures of all Heat API backends, when *some* API requests *might* end up with long running TCP connections expiring without tcpka. Whatever overhead it brings, the issue of cascading APIs failure shall never happen. The follow-up could be done for other services, like Neutron, but as I noted, that's Heat API's HA for NFV to be hardened in the first place. Then later, we can estimate benefits versus overheads for other services that also has a notion of "long running" API requests.
oh, I see now, that had to be a deep merge...

web/src/containers/status/Pipeline.jsx.message: I'd suggest hiding this in an ExpandableSection: https://www.patternfly.org/v4/components/expandable-section#basic

I'm of two minds about this.  In the long run, we probably shouldn't have these on the status page, and instead, operators should have nice dashboards.  Or, perhaps in an expandable section as Matthieu suggests.

In the short term, as we work toward 5.0, it might be helpful for us to have them front-and-center as we observe new behaviors.  And I think if that's the case, we don't want to hide them with an expandable section.  But they also shouldn't be more prominent than the description.  :)

So how about:

1) We move them below the description and wrap them with <small>.  Maybe even greying them out a bit would be good too?
2) When we get close to 5.0, we drop them or put them in an expandable section?
Since the confusion for the user seems to come from the term "queue" I'm going to remove it. I'll also add a tooltip with a short explanation.

Then how about a popover to explain what a queue refers to in that context, since the term is already used within pipelines? The dual use might be a bit confusing to non-operators.

Or we can wait until we see enough users asking what these mean before putting in the extra effort. :)

I don't know if it's just me and my screen setup, but I don't see a lot of difference between this text and the pipelines' descriptions, in terms of color and size. How about using italics to make a clear distinction?

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I love that this is getting a real use now.  We added the uuid to the layout originally just to help in debugging memory leaks, and hopefully this change will continue to reduce the chances of that.  :)

I'm not following this.  Where does the executor client need this?  I see a path from the manager to the model.  Plus, anything with the job graph should have access to the item and therefore pipeline, so should have access to the layout cache.  Maybe we can simplify this?

That makes sense, but let's change the commit message so that it says that.  The executor client *does* have access to the layout, so it's confusing as written.  Saying "we want to restrict layout access to job freezing so that fewer actions (like creating a build request after a job is frozen) require access to it" would help reviewers and others in the future looking at the git history.  :)

The executor client needs the project metadata for constructing the gearman params (see changes in executor/common.py). If we require a layout in order to access the project metadata, it means we MUST (re-)create a layout on all schedulers.

Out working assumption is that we can limit the use of the layout to job freezing. In that case we only need to re-create an item's layout on another scheduler if a following item needs it as a fallback.

Besides the scale-out scheduler use-case, storing the project metadata independent of the layout is also required for the optimization in I9b9657a18664e515ecc11a47f8624b5f248084c4.
Updated the commit message to make the intention more clear.
That's great; let's just add this to that comment in the Layout class, so that when someone says "what is a layout uuid" we have that as a handy reference.  :)
Ack

zuul/configloader.py.message:
I think that covers it.  I'm happy now with the understanding that a layout UUID represents a unique combination of (tenant layout + position in queue), and that any potential future schedulers can re-create them.  I think that's what we need to document to help people with brain patterns like mine to understand it.  :)

That also helps me understand that the code path where we create a layout with an existing uuid can't happen in this patch.  I'm happy to make the change now, or we can do it later (I think we have found what we need to document either way).

This change seems to be reaching pretty far forward, in that it's making changes in aid of future changes, but doesn't fully describe why.  This is a significant change in meaning for what a layout UUID is, so it's important to understand fully and document.

Why would another scheduler need to create that layout then?

How would it create the same layout given that the inputs may have changed?
This seems counter-intuitive to me.  Why are we specifying a universally unique id for a new object.  what are we reusing here?

I agree that this might be something that we should rather do in a later change when the context of why this is necessary is more obvious. I think I'll remove it as it is unrelated to the rest of this change.

Re. why another scheduler would need to create the layout: it might be required as a fallback layout for following items. If item A's layout is created for job freezing on scheduler ONE and later a following item B's job graph is frozen on scheduler TWO we need to re-create the layout of item A on scheduler TWO as B needs it as fallback layout and it's not in the layout cache.

Re. how we would create the "same" layout: I don't expect the inputs to change (the inputs being the chain of items ahead; position in the queue) and the tenant layout) without the layout UUID changing:

1. In case the tenant layout changed we would re-enqueue the pipeline and with that reset the layout UUID to None (done in manager/__init__.py#61). If we need the layout again as a fallback for following items we will create a new layout (inputs changed) with a new UUID.

2. In case of a gate reset (position in the queue changed) the pipeline manager will call resetAllBuilds() and with that also reset the layout UUID (see model.py#2359).

Do you have any other inputs in mind that could lead to a different layout?

This is for the case when we created a layout for this item on one scheduler but it is later required on a different one. Initially the item's layout UUID will be None, so a new layout UUID must be created. If the layout UUID is already set, we need to re-create the layout and since it's the "same" layout (though a different object) we also use the same UUID. The item's layout UUID should only change if its position in the queue changed or it was reset during a re-enqueue.

zuul/manager/__init__.py.message: I'm curious why you decided to put this on the manager instead of the pipeline itself?  Most of the "runtime" data are in the pipeline (the items themselves, for instance; and of course the layouts are right now since they're on the items).  It seems like it would have worked just as well either way.

It feels to me like the layout cache is less of a runtime data thing and more of an implementation detail with most of the "mechanics" in the manager. I don't have a strong opinion on where to put the cache, so I'm fine with moving it to the pipeline if you prefer that.

This is a good comment, but on a first pass, because of the way it's written and since it appears at the top of the method, it looks like it's saying that this method does the opposite of what it does.  I think if you said "First collect all the config...."  and then added a comment below saying "Then find the current errors which aren't also in the parent" or something like that...
Ack, done with the next PS.

Is the layout_uuid ever expected to be false? if so would this be better as:

  if not item.layout_uuid:
      return None

  self.log.debug("...")
  layout = self._getLayout(item)
  ...

See below for my thoughts on protecting from a null key.

Regarding the conditional log line, I think what this means is: there exists a theoretical layout for this item, but we don't have it.  We need to recreate it.  I think this can only happen in a multi-scheduler situation.  Because in a single scheduler situation, the only way for an item to have a layout uuid assigned to it is to get it from a layout.  Meanwhile, if item.layout_uuid is None, then that means no one has ever made a layout for this item, so it needs to be created ("calculated") for the first time.

I was confused about the reason for logging here only when we have a cache miss when we expect a hit rather than a miss due to not being seen before. Sounds like this is useful for understanding why layouts are calculated at different times in the logs.
Yes, this log line will become useful when we have multiple schedulers running.

Looking at the child change has helped me understand this better. I think we should consider checking for a None item.layout_uuid above so that we don't somehow accidentally start caching a layout for None (and then sharing that between changes).

Then I think what you wanted the condition here to be is if not item.layout_uuid so that we log the recalculation only when there isn't already something cached. However, I think that since we've fallen through to here that is already the case and we can just drop this condition entirely.

If the goal is to be defensive about caching a layout with a null key, it seems like this would be the best place to do it:
        if layout.uuid is None: raise Exception
Because otherwise, item.layout_uuid is expected to be either a string or None within this method, so I don't know that it makes sense to test that anywhere else.

I agree this would be the place to address the None key concern. That said after some discussion on IRC, corvus pointed out this is the only place we write to the cache. We also always have a uuid on a layout. Below we update item.layout_uuid from the layout so it should always be valid and not None. This should be fine as is.
My above question is related to this condition as well. It seems to be the opposite of what we attempt above.

zuul/model.py.message:
That makes sense; another way to put it is that the project metadata are needed in order to run the jobs in the job graph, and are therefore arguably part of the frozen job graph.

I think your updated comment helps, thanks.

This comment could use more information about why it must be independent of the layout due to the buildset global repo state.  If we're at this point, we should have a layout that was build from the item's merge job.  (And obviously this is the thing I was suggesting we might be able to avoid in the comment on the commit message.)

Yea, I think this should be rephrased as the reference to the global repo state is a bit misleading.

The thing is that we might NOT have a layout in certain situations:

1. a layout can be reset during re-enqueue w/o re-freezing the job graph. Since we want to avoid re-creating the layout just for the project metadata (that's the optimization in I9b9657a18664e515ecc11a47f8624b5f248084c4) we store it on the job graph instead.

2. if we freeze the job graph on one scheduler but job execution (which needs the project metadata) is requested on a different scheduler we can avoid re-recreating the layout.

All of these places where we pass in the layout and the layout ahead seem like places where errors could easily sneak in.  Can we keep something like the old code here and obtain the layout ahead here?

A getLayoutAhead() method seems like it would be really nice (whether that's on QueueItem or Pipeline, or PipelineManager).
Makes sense. I think we can simply use the manager's getFallbackLayout() method.
As mentioned elsewhere, the idea of having duplicate uuids seems counterintuitive.
See my reply to the other comment. Maybe it makes sense to have a comment here explaining why we allow setting the layout UUID.

This is where we should add the comment from the commit message; but also, if you're going to remove the other thing, you should remove this comment.

Honestly, since I'm asking for another patchset, I'd say put it back in.  I think we've worked through it now, we might as well call it done.  :)

this is because the heiradata and modules share a folder and we expect them to be mounted into the container for container-puppet.sh.  It's all terrible but i'm trying to see if i can get the config bits working elsewhere without completely rewriting all the things.

Isn't puppet config bits are always build locally on nodes? And we only want to fetch the produced results back to undercloud? And if those would be fetched by the source {{ inventory_hostname }} involved paths, why do we need to alter the cname?..

These patches are to move the puppet config off of the node. cname is the name of the container when running so if it's being executed elsewhere, it includes the remote hostname so you'd end up with controller-0-container-puppet-heat-api and controller-1-container-puppet-heat-api on the system that executes this.  Right now i'm just investigating if it's even possible to do what i'm proposing. This would be to move the configuration generation off of the remote systems so we just publish configs + containers on the nodes rather than generating config and container bits on the target system.
if they get built on the undercloud (or elsewhere) we can't duplicate the names. they need to be unique to the nodes

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_ovs_dpdk/t.message: I can see that the whole playbook is written this way. But I have a question here, due to my lack of knowledge on this matter, is there difference between set the minimum thread to 0 and remove the key?

Removing the key, will remove it from the OVS db and ovs would use the default value, in the case for  pmd-auto-lb-load-threshold, it would be 95, as state in https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man5/ovs-vswitchd.conf.db.5.html.

This should be 

  state: absent

if you intend to clear the setting.
Otherwise we don't really need to have separate tasks to enable/disable the feature, IMO.
+1 this could be combined into a single task using the state keyword -- https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/openvswitch/openvswitch/openvswitch_db_module.html#parameter-state

I think what Kevin was indicating is that you can do something like:

  state: "{{ 'present' if tripleo_ovs_dpdk_pmd_auto_lb|bool else 'absent' }}"

and then not need separate Tasks to Enable/Disable

validations_libs/tests/cli/fakes.py.message:
I would add multiple key=value comma-separated as well.

foo1=bar1,foo2=bar2

I am quite aware of the design and I know that I have to pass multiple --extra-vars argument!
I didn't ask for a redesign here, I would just like to see that case tested.
That's it! ;-)

I would too, but the CLI isn't designed to accept such input. 
It might be an oversight, but the way things are now, if you supply a comma separated list to the CLI as extra vars, it will fail with the 'ArgumentTypeError'.
If you want to pass multiple variables, you need specify them in their own `--extra-vas` arg. 

Redesigning it is possible but beyond scope of this patch.

enhanced-policies/README.md.message: here you have "project_readonly" but earlier you have "project_reader", which is it?
the "project_readonly" role doesn't seem to be used anywhere else in this commmit, which seems a bit odd given that we're explicitly adding it.  Is that intentional?
why is the role creation a manual step rather than part of the application manifest?

Yes. In fact, you can call a role that is not on the policy whatever you want and it would have the same results here. Actually, whomever holds a role that is not admin, project_admin or project_member will have the same privileges.
Using these roles and policies are opt-in from the user's standpoint, we don't want that to be default on stx-openstack.

under what circumstances would it delete the existing configuration, and what does the customer have to do in order to use it safely?

It sure looks like if the customer has already created any of the resources that it will clean up then their resources will be deleted as well.  If this is the case, perhaps we should do the tests in a newly-created project so that deleting resources from that project *cannot* impact any resources that the customer has set up?

We do create a couple of new projects to run those tests on (project1 and project2) on the pytest fixtures of the patches 2 to 5 and create the resources based on some common patterns that we use to filter what we are removing. Maybe we should use a less "common" pattern though (like instead of using "subnet1" we could use "test-policy-subnet1"). We will do that the follow up patches and adjust the cleanup.

enhanced-policies/cinder-policy-override.message:
Correct policy should be the following, to allow project members and readonly users to view volume image metadata, such as the Volume Source image:

        volume_extension:volume_image_metadata: rule:admin_or_owner

Single quotes sometimes cause misinterpretation to "FALSE", instead of "ALLOWED for ALL"

Change all single quotes '' to double quotes "". This is general. REPLACE ALL.

The correct rule is the following, to allow the display of "volume image source" in Horizon

volume_image_metadata: rule:admin_or_owner
Do we not use the "read only" role here at all?
which of these are default and which are different from a "typical" setup?

The idea here is to document where we are different from a typical upstream setup, so that if the upstream changes we have a better idea whether we might want to also change it on our end or if it's something we're specifically setting because we want it.
One have to override the whole policy anyway, so it doesn't really matter the typical setup.

I'm a bit confused...how does the "owner" play into this?  Wouldn't we want all users with the "project_admin" role for a given project to be able to act as an admin for that project even if they weren't the owner?
In Openstack, the ownership of the resources is always the project, not the user. So read this as "project_admin on the project that owns the backup"

enhanced-policies/glance-policy-override.message:
Single quotes sometimes cause misinterpretation to "FALSE", instead of "ALLOWED for ALL"

Change all single quotes '' to double quotes "". This is general. REPLACE ALL.

enhanced-policies/horizon-policy-overrid.message:
Single quotes sometimes cause misinterpretation to "FALSE", instead of "ALLOWED for ALL"

Change all single quotes '' to double quotes "". This is general. REPLACE ALL.

There is a double "rule:rule" here. Correct rule is:

backup:restore: rule:admin_or_projectadmin_owner
why does horizon have duplicates of the policies for all the other components?  shouldn't the policies of the other components apply regardless of what is configured for horizon?

Do we document somewhere what specific items need to be different between the backend policies and Horizon?  If not we should put it in the source somewhere for the next person that needs to modify permissions.  Ideally we should be using a shared set of permissions and a list of deltas that override it for Horizon in order to make this explicit, but I recognize that we probably wouldn't be able to do that in the near term.

The problem is that on horizon, the policies prevents the visualization of certain elements on the UI, so they doesn't exactly match the backend policies. Those instructions actually makes a yaml file that would need to be added into the charts anyway. The policies here were tested for all capabilities described on the test cases.

Alternately, https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/contributor/topics/policy.html has instructions on dynamically generating policy files from the other components.

Barring that, we should define these policies in one place and then incorporate them in both horizon and their "native" policy.   Duplication of policies should be avoided if at all possible as it's just *asking* for trouble when one gets modified and the other doesn't.

reference/charter.rst.message:
Also:
WG membership and involvement
Leading a MeetUp or a session at an OpenInfra Days or Ops Meetup event
Participating in the User Survey

Teams have, from time to time, recognized valued reviewers who haven't been contributing code directly as extra-ATCs. It's probably fine to mention them as a class of possible additions, but you open the TC to a lot of subjective determination there to decide who qualifies under that provision. Or you could just rely on teams to continue that practice on their own if it seems relevant to them.
Do we also count active reviewers in this list?
Active Reviewer are very valid AC and project can continue to propose them as extra-ATC as they do currently.

> Also:
> WG membership and involvement

Makes sense.

> Leading a MeetUp or a session at an OpenInfra Days or Ops Meetup event
> Participating in the User Survey

These are pretty low bars aren't they? "Filled out a web survey that one time" seems like a pretty minor amount of involvement. I'm not sure about the meetup thing and how much that really indicates involvement in the project itself, so much as just being an enthusiast or user.

I know we're trying to increase the scope, but one could argue that we're approaching "any foundation member" right?

> Do we also count active reviewers in this list?

Personally, I think the reviewer bar is too low. Not because it wouldn't include a ton of great people, but more just because mining the data would include looots of people that auto-+1 patches after a core.

> *Regularly* or any better word to describe the active participation.

Agree, I think this needs to be a human-level assessment of the contribution.

>>Also:
>>WG membership and involvement
>Makes sense.

Please note "WG" here means "Working groups under Technical committee", this one https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/working-groups.html
 
>>Leading a MeetUp or a session at an OpenInfra Days or Ops Meetup event
>>Participating in the User Survey

>These are pretty low bars aren't they? "Filled out a web survey that one time" seems like a pretty minor amount of involvement. >I'm not sure about the meetup thing and how much that really indicates involvement in the project itself, so much as just being >an enthusiast or user.
>I know we're trying to increase the scope, but one could argue that we're approaching "any foundation >member" right?

Indeed, we have to be careful on this and it should not be like we open vote for "any foundation member". 

We can list something like below:
* Bug triaging not tracked in Gerrit
* SIG membership and involvement
* Technical committee Working groups members
* Regularly participates in code review or team feedback/discussions etc.

*Regularly* or any better word to describe the active participation.

specs/wallaby/vpnaas-ovn.rst.message:
This is for project neutron-vpnaas, right? A new type of agent with different L2/L3 driver, but reuse the 'swan' VPN drivers [1].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron-vpnaas/tree/master/neutron_vpnaas/services/vpn/device_drivers

Yes, for neutron-vpnaas. The new agent does not provide L2/L3 driver functions, it's only there to start the *swan process and manage a namespace for it. There will be separate swan drivers to do that, derived from the existing ones.
nit: this is not related to the "neutron server", right? It's been already introduced on L26
I changed the wording. This sentence was meant to introduce the following one.
What happens when VPN agent dies but the gateway port is still bound to the same node. Is it the VPN scheduler responsibility to change the GW port binding location?
Why this transit network needs to be managed by Neutron API? Can You elaborate more on that?

In my understanding, it is mainly to simplify the maintenance. If we create transit network in neutron, all resources in the OVN side would be a mirror of neutron resources. This would be simpler and I think it is a good  compromise.

If the lswitch for the transit network is created directly in the OVN Northbound DB, sync scripts like neutron-ovn-db-sync-util will detect inconsistencies with the Neutron DB and might delete the seemingly unwanted lswitches. On the other hand, if the transit network is created via Neutron the Neutron DB and OVN NB are kept in sync and one could use neutron-ovn-db-sync-util to re-generate the OVN DB if necessary.
Do You mean L3 service plugin or "ovn-l3" service plugin?
"L3 plugin" refers to the OVN L3 router service plugin (which provides the get_router, add/remove_router_interface, add/remove_extraroutes functions)
does that mean that we will again need to use rabbitmq for communication in Neutron?

Thanks for updating it. The proposal sounds reasnable to me. While neutron OVN deployment does not use rabbitmq, other OpenStack components like nova still require rabbitmq, so I don't think using rabbitmq is so much extra thing.

I added more text to explain the choices. Since OVN does not support VPN configuration itself the configuration needs to be communicated outside of OVN north/southbound databases. The existing VPNaaS plugin used rabbitmq, so it would be the least complex change if we keep it.
For the liveness checks there is an alternative though: to use the same mechanism as the OVN metadata agent via an additional Chassis_Private external_id.
My current proposal is to keep using rabbitmq for configuration updates and status updates, and don't use rabbitmq for the liveness check (instead use the algorithm of other OVN agents).
Looks it is true, there will be a new python agent for Neutron in OVN cluster. Something like ovn-metadata-agent I guess.
Just note that ovn-metadata-agent doesn't use RPC but OVN databases to report liveness.

Yes, the current design of the VPN agent uses rabbitmq for aliveness updates. That part could be changed to the way the OVN metadata agent works for aliveness.
But there's more rabbitmq: The existing vpnaas plugin used rabbitmq for syncing the VPN configuration as well and the new OVN vpnaas drivers don't change that.
I added a short paragraph to the spec to document that rabbitmq is still used for communication between neutron server and VPN agent to sync the VPN configuration. Will that be acceptable?

Is this public IP address on the external network automatically allocated when a VPN service is created?
The spec says there is no API change so I guess the allocated public IP address will be visible to a user via "external_v4_ip" or "external_v6_ip". Is my understanding correct?
Anyway it would be nice to mention it in the "REST API impact" section.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html?expanded=create-vpn-endpoint-group-detail,create-vpn-service-detail#vpnaas-2-0-vpn-vpnservices-ikepolicies-ipsecpolicies-endpoint-groups-ipsec-site-connections
Right, the external IP of the VPN service appears in external_v4_ip/external_v6_ip. I added that note to the spec, also in the REST API impact section.

Who will be the owner of this "transit network"? My question is whther it is visible to REST API user or it is only visible to admin. IMHO it should be visible only to admin (as we do for L3-HA network)

In our current proposed implementation the transit network and the extra gateway port are only visible to admin. The extra routes added to the router will be visible to the user. That's why the "transit subnet" is put into the user project too. I understand this may be debatable, but we thought to make it visible to somehow explain the extra routes, which we cannot hide.

I am not sure which is better to make "transit subnet" visible to users. From user perspective, users will see at least "transit subnet" OR "extra routes" in a router. Users do not create both of them, so they could be confused. 

If "transit subnet" is visible to users, users potentialy specifies it for other use cases (for example, a subnet when creating a port, a subnet for a router interface) as it is included in a subnet list.

I am not sure which is better: (a) to make "transit subnet" visible to users, or (b) to make "extra routes to a peer CIDR in a router" without exposign "transit subnet", or (c) any other options.

At the moment my vote is (b) but I would like to hear more opinions from the author and other reviews.

All device_owner used by neutron internally have "network:" prefix.
It is better to add "network:" prefix.

(Note: "neutron:" prefix is also defined in neutron-lib, but according to my search result it is (was) only used by neutron-lbaas and I think it can be dropped now as neutron-lbaas was retired.)
I updated the spec to use the correct "network:" prefix.

In our existing device owner naming, we don't use abbrevs like "4". How about using "-for-" instead or just "-network-vpn-"?

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/src/branch/master/neutron_lib/constants.py#L43-L82
I updated the spec (and the proposed implementation) to use the name "vpn-transit-network-{router_id}". Similarly for the subnet too.

L.78-80 says a (extra) gateway port and a transit network are created when the first VPN service is created, but a VPN namespace is created when the first ipsec site connection is created. Is there any reason we cannot do them at the same timing?

(I didn't check if only one VPN service can be assigned to one router, but the spec uses a specific CIDR for a transit network for a router, so I assume the relationship between a router and a VPN serivce is 1:1 mapping.)
Thanks for the clarification. My memory is ambiguous in several points. Your reply clarifies the situation and it totally sounds reasonable to me.

The gateway port and transit network are created with the VPN service to be able to include the external_v4_ip/external_v6_ip when the creation finishes.
On the other hand the agent is only notified on site connection changes. That's an approach we kept from the original VPNaaS plugin. The Swan process will only be created if there is some ipsec site connection. We only add the namespace creation.

On the relationship router / VPN service(s): The original VPNaaS implementation only supports a 1:1 mapping (max 1 VPN service per router). Changes to allow an 1:n relationship are not covered by this spec now. We would like to allow that in the future too, but might address that in a separate RFE. But even multiple VPN services on the same router could share the transit network and the extra gateway port. That's why the specific CIDR should be fine.

nit: The indent of L.130-133 needs to align with "create" at L.128. Otherwise, we will see unnecessary vertical line [1].

[1] https://storage.bhs.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_708/767292/4/check/openstack-tox-docs/708e1f4/docs/specs/wallaby/vpnaas-ovn.html#vpn-namespace-management

The 'address' attribute of 'self.tags' will be a string if it's present. However, we'll never use this string form. Instead, we'll always parse this (via the 'WhitelistPciAddress' constructor) and use the *parsed* form. If we continued to save this unparsed form to 'self.address' before updating it with the parsed form, our type hint would need to be:

  ty.Union[WhitelistPciAddress, str, None]

and everything that uses this attribute would need to start handling strings, even though at runtime they will never see a string here. This kind of thing affect us elsewhere. Take this example:

  keep_going = input('Enter yes to continue: ')
  keep_going = keep_going == 'yes'

Including type hints, we'd get

  keep_going: ty.Union[str, bool] = input('Enter yes to continue: ')
  keep_going = keep_going == 'yes'

But we'll never actually see a string after initial processing, so we can instead do:

  _keep_going = input('Enter yes to continue: ')
  keep_going: bool = keep_going == 'yes'

swift/common/db_replicator.py.message:
This is better then it was. But still really just 1000. The way the db replicators work, which isn't very intuitive is we have, say the container replicator running as a daemon. It has a per_diff (which you've rightly defaulted with a constant towards the top of this file) because the account and container replicators inherit the db replicator.

This replicator daemon calls a REPLICATE http verb in container-server (or account) WSGI server:  https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/container/server.py#L810-L828

Which is using an instance of the ReplicatorRPC object where in here, who talks and deals with the db_replicator. Because the ReplicatorRPC is instanciated from the container and account servers, we may need to add a per_diff option there which can be piped into the creation of the rpc object.

I think that's the missing peice of the puzzle 😊

deployment/keystone/keystone-container-p.message:
Doing this in post_upgrade_tasks is fine for systems undergoing FFU, just bear in mind [1] explains why the original code used external_deploy_tasks. The issue is the bug [2] doesn't get triggered until *after* FFU, so there was a need for the patch to "fix" systems that had already undergone FFU and were now broken.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/757414/1//COMMIT_MSG#L26
[2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1897761

os_keystone_service _is_ idempotent, so using it in both places should work. It's unfortunate the task needs to be done in two places, but I understand the logical place is here (post_upgrade_tasks) and the other (external_deploy_tasks) is required just to fix broken upgrades.
Thanks a lot for clarifying Alan

I wonder, if the os_keystone_service is idempotent, then it should be fine to leave it as an external_deploy_task and an post_upgrade_task, shouldn't it? This way we cover both scenarios, when the system is undergoing FFU and systems that already went through it.
Could this be replaced with "run_once: true" above L865?
